excerpt: Contemporary structure housing exhibits on pre-Columbian gold, ceramics & stones, with a cafe.
detail_description: The Gold Museum, located in the historic city center of Bogota, is a contemporary structure that houses an extensive collection of pre-Columbian gold, ceramics, and stones. It is home to over 34 thousand pieces made of gold and tumbaga, showcasing the art and goldsmithing used by various indigenous communities in Colombia.
name: Gold Museum
address: Cra. 6 #15-88, Santa Fé, Bogotá, Cundinamarca, Colombia

excerpt: La Candelaria is Bogota’s vibrant heart, with landmarks like the colonial-era cathedral and neoclassical Capitol flanking Bolivar Plaza. Narrow streets lined with shops selling emeralds and handicrafts lead to cultural hotspots like the Gold Museum, with pre-Columbian artifacts, and Museo Botero, showing international art in a colonial mansion. Casual eateries serve dishes like ajiaco (chicken and potato soup).
detail_description: La Candelaria, located in Bogota, is a historic and vibrant neighborhood known for its colonial-era cathedral, neoclassical Capitol, and Bolivar Plaza. The area features narrow streets with shops selling emeralds and handicrafts, as well as cultural hotspots like the Gold Museum and Museo Botero. This neighborhood is also home to various museums, theaters, universities, and historic libraries set against the backdrop of cobbled streets and Spanish colonial buildings.
name: La Candelaria

excerpt: Mountain in the center of the city with a church & shrine, popular with pilgrims & tourists.
detail_description: Monserrate, a mountain located in the center of Bogota, is a popular destination for both pilgrims and tourists. At 3,152 meters high, it offers stunning panoramic views of the capital city. The mountain is home to the Sanctuary of Monserrate and features expansive gardens perfect for leisurely strolls. Additionally, visitors can enjoy dining at exclusive restaurants offering local and international cuisine.
name: Monserrate

excerpt: Florentine Gothic Catholic temple from the early 20th century with a unique striped paint scheme.
detail_description: Santuario Nuestra Señora del Carmen is a captivating Catholic temple in Bogota, Colombia. This unique church, built in the early 20th century, showcases a striking Florentine Gothic style with influences from Byzantine and Arabic art. Its most distinctive feature is the red and white horizontal stripes adorning both its interior and exterior. The church stands as a proud testament to history, having undergone restoration due to pollution and humidity damage in the late 1980s.
name: Santuario Nuestra Señora del Carmen

excerpt: Spacious city center surrounded by a cathedral & important buildings with notable architecture.
detail_description: Plaza de Bolívar is a historic city center in Bogota, Colombia, surrounded by significant buildings and notable architecture. The area offers a mix of old and new, with the Plaza once being a stage for bullfights but now juxtaposed with modern structures like the Palace of Justice and Lievano Palace. Visitors can explore nearby attractions such as the Metropolitan Cathedral Basilica of the Immaculate Conception and take part in graffiti tours led by individuals involved in the urban art scene.
name: Plaza de Bolívar

excerpt: Prominent museum in a colonial mansion featuring works by Fernando Botero & other global artists.
detail_description: The Botero Museum, located in a colonial mansion in the heart of Bogota's Historic Center, is a must-visit for art enthusiasts. The museum showcases an extensive collection of works by Colombian artist Fernando Botero, known for his larger-than-life art. Donated to the state by the artist himself, the museum maintains Botero's original arrangement from its inauguration in 2000.
name: Botero Museum

excerpt: Upmarket Chapinero features a mix of mountainside residential sections and commercial zones with glitzy malls. Fine-dining areas like Parque de la 93 and Zona G buzz in the evening, as do the glamorous clubs and bars of Zona Rosa. The Chapinero Central neighborhood also has a lively gay scene. Landmarks include El Chicó Museum, a colonial hacienda set in parkland, and 19th-century Our Lady of Lourdes Basilica.
detail_description: Chapinero is a vibrant district in Bogota, known for its mix of upscale residential areas and commercial zones. The neighborhood offers a variety of dining options, from fine-dining areas like Parque de la 93 and Zona G to the lively nightlife in Zona Rosa. Chapinero Central is also recognized for its vibrant gay scene. Visitors can explore landmarks such as El Chicó Museum and Our Lady of Lourdes Basilica.
name: Chapinero

excerpt: Bustling weekly gathering of outdoor vendors selling arts, crafts, food & gifts, plus entertainment.
detail_description: The Usaquén Flea Market is a vibrant weekly event in Bogota, Colombia, where outdoor vendors gather to sell a variety of goods including arts, crafts, food, and gifts. The market takes place in the charming cobblestone streets of Usaquén and offers a diverse array of products from luxurious jewelry to artisanal handbags. Visitors can explore the colonial neighborhood while discovering unique handmade items and enjoying delicious fresh foods.
name: Usaquén Flea Market
address: Calle 119 Con Carrera 6a, Bogotá, Cundinamarca, Colombia

excerpt: Trendy Usaquén is a foodie hotspot. Asian fusion eateries, upscale French bistros and mellow garden cafes cluster around Usaquén Park, the district’s focal point, while brewpubs and chic cocktail bars keep the scene buzzing until late. Crowds gather on Sundays for the Usaquén flea market, featuring street musicians, puppet shows, gourmet food stands and stalls selling handmade jewelry to local coffee beans.
detail_description: Usaquén, located in the north of Bogota, is a trendy neighborhood known for its vibrant food scene and lively atmosphere. The area is home to a variety of dining options, including Asian fusion restaurants, upscale French bistros, and charming garden cafes centered around Usaquén Park. In addition to its culinary offerings, Usaquén hosts a popular flea market on Sundays called Mercado de las Pulgas de Usaquen.
name: Usaquén

detail_description: The Edificio Administrativo Museo del Oro in Colombia showcases the expertise of the country's indigenous people in working with gold and bronze. The museum displays a wide array of meticulously crafted jewelry, including earrings, nose plates, necklaces, breastplates, and small sculptures depicting animals. These artifacts offer a glimpse into the pre-colonial life in Colombia. It is an excellent place to immerse oneself in the history of Colombia and appreciate the intricate craftsmanship of its ancient inhabitants.
name: Edificio Administrativo Museo del Oro

detail_description: La Puerta Falsa Restaurant, a 200-year-old establishment located near Plaza de Bolivar, is a beloved spot for locals and visitors alike. This cozy cafe has been frequented by well-known figures such as writers, actors, and ex-presidents. The menu features traditional Bogotano home-cooked meals including Ajiaco and Chocolate Completo.
name: La Puerta Falsa Restaurant

excerpt: Large, busy city green space with a walking/biking path,  a lake for boating & a kids' playground.
detail_description: Simón Bolívar Park, also known as the lung of Bogota, is a sprawling green space that offers a variety of activities for visitors. With 113 hectares of land, the park features walking and biking paths, playgrounds for kids, and several lakes where you can go boating. It has been a venue for numerous events and has hosted famous artists and even two popes.
name: Parque Metropolitano Simón Bolívar
address: Av. Calle 53 Avenida La Esmeralda #s/n y, Bogotá, Cundinamarca, Colombia

detail_description: Andrés Carne de Res is a legendary steakhouse in Bogota, Colombia, known for offering a unique Colombian experience. The restaurant is famous for its stellar empanadas and all-night, alcohol-fueled benders that create a fiesta atmosphere. With a 75-page menu featuring succulent steaks, arepas, and ceviche, diners can enjoy hearty Colombian cuisine.
name: Andrés Carne de Res Chía

excerpt: Historic square featuring a modest fountain, colonial buildings, cafes, restaurants & more.
detail_description: Plazoleta Chorro de Quevedo, also known as Pueblito Rolo, is a historic square located in the highest part of Bogota's La Candelaria neighborhood. It is believed to be the site where the city was founded and features colonial buildings, cobblestone streets, and a modest fountain. The area is popular with street artists and college students, creating a lively atmosphere.
name: Plazoleta Chorro de Quevedo

excerpt: Large museum with 20,000+ artifacts from the 16th century to modern times, plus a restaurant & shop.
detail_description: The Museo Nacional de Colombia is a large museum housing over 20,000 artifacts dating from the 16th century to modern times. It offers a comprehensive insight into the diverse ethnic and cultural influences that have shaped Colombia's history. The museum boasts an impressive collection of pre-Columbian art showcasing the skill and creativity of indigenous peoples, as well as more recent works by renowned Colombian artists such as Fernando Botero and Alejandro Obregon.
name: Museo Nacional de Colombia

detail_description: Zona Rosa 1.1, also known as Zona T due to its T-shape, is a lively district in Bogota where locals go to party. It is located in the El Retiro neighborhood and is considered the city's entertainment hub. The area boasts trendy nightclubs, live DJ venues, classy bars, and restaurants catering to various tastes. Zona Rosa offers a vibrant nightlife scene with hundreds of well-heeled residents enjoying late-night parties on weekends.
name: Zona Rosa 1.1

excerpt: This historic, presidential residence with stately architecture offers guided tours by appointment.
detail_description: Casa de Nariño, also known as Palacio de Nariño, is the official residence and primary workplace of the President of Colombia. This historic building, constructed in the neoclassical style in the 17th century, stands as a symbol of the country's executive power. It holds significant historical value and offers guided tours by appointment.
name: Casa de Nariño
address: Cra. 8 #7 - 26, La Candelaria, Bogotá, Cundinamarca, Colombia

excerpt: Neoclassical national theater building inaugurated in 1892 & hosting regular major performances.
detail_description: Teatro Colón Bogotá is a neoclassical national theater building that was inaugurated in 1892 and is considered one of the oldest opera houses in the Americas. The architecture, inspired by the Parisian Palais Garnier, showcases delicate ornamentation dominated by frescoes of the six Greek muses painted by Italian masters.
name: Teatro Colón Bogotá

excerpt: Spacious city center surrounded by a cathedral & important buildings with notable architecture.
detail_description: Plaza Bolivar, located in Bogota, has been a focal point of religious and cultural activities for centuries. Initially serving as a temporary open-air cathedral upon the arrival of Spanish colonists in the 16th century, it has also hosted a livestock market and circus. During Christmas, the plaza is adorned with vibrant fairy lights, creating a festive atmosphere. Despite being crowded, visitors can enjoy the bustling ambiance while exploring street food vendors and souvenir shops.
name: Plaza de Bolívar

detail_description: Ciclovia Boyaca between 170 and 134 is a popular cycling route in Bogota, Colombia. This scenic path spans between the 170th and 134th streets, offering cyclists a safe and enjoyable way to explore the city. The route is known for its well-maintained paths, beautiful greenery, and vibrant atmosphere. It provides a great opportunity for both locals and tourists to stay active while taking in the sights of Bogota.
name: Ciclovia boyaca entre la 170 y 134
